text: Consider building a local workstation with nvme storage and a threadripper CPU instead

elements.text: Consider building a local workstation with nvme storage and a threadripper CPU instead

text: That works if you have the upfront capital and can keep it busy. One thing I would say on the AWS stack is see if you can use spot instances if you're doing a lot of this: reduces costs a lot, and obviously upfront costs disappear. I am biased as it's my employer, but I'd agree that if you can do the upfront cost and keep it busy and don't mind the occasional upgrade cycle, Mo’s suggestion can be cost effective.

elements.text: That works if you have the upfront capital and can keep it busy. text: Actually I just noticed in Virginia there are some instance types with 448. But pricey. Can knock 80% off with spot instances I imagine, but I'd go 128, and also spot. Means if you're doing 20 hours a week of backtesting, you'd pay about $700 over a year.

text:
Found the <https://github.com/liampauling/flumine/pull/539/commits/9d41d1486bd22cb7d80317774a88efa0ecd279b8|bug>, simulation code wasn't executing when a cancel/update/replace was in flight, looks like its been here since the beginning :man-facepalming:

Resorted to going through order by order in excel to find this..

text:
I have experimented with a few things on AWS lambda/spot instances/fargate/ecs and they all work well but there is always the upfront time cost in getting them setup and without a sophisticated framework on top it isn't exactly simple to quickly run something.

I agree with <@UBS7QANF3> as since purchasing a decent laptop (M1) the amount of backtests I carry out has skyrocketed as I can just press f5 and forgot about it

elements.text:
I have experimented with a few things on AWS lambda/spot instances/fargate/ecs and they all work well but there is always the upfront time cost in getting them setup and without a sophisticated framework on top it isn't exactly simple to quickly run something.

I agree with
as since purchasing a decent laptop (M1) the amount of backtests I carry out has skyrocketed as I can just press f5 and forgot about it

text: Yeah, I'm planning an M1 laptop next year. I hear you. You need to think about the workload and plan for it, and there is definitely upfront cost. The flip side is you're then able to scale (if you want to), run many parallel tests (if you want to), and as new compute instances come online, you can embrace that without much upfront cost. It's whether you want to do something quick and dirty or have a platform for long-term testing of ideas, I think.

elements.text: Yeah, I'm planning an M1 laptop next year. I hear you. You need to think about the workload and plan for it, and there is definitely upfront cost. The flip side is you're then able to scale (if you want to), run many parallel tests (if you want to), and as new compute instances come online, you can embrace that without much upfront cost. It's whether you want to do something quick and dirty or have a platform for long-term testing of ideas, I think.

text: And for me - as somebody who has been using cloud since the early days, with 25+ years software dev experience - the upfront cost of the cloud stack is a great deal less than it is for many. I definitely get that.

elements.text: And for me - as somebody who has been using cloud since the early days, with 25+ years software dev experience - the upfront cost of the cloud stack is a great deal less than it is for many. I definitely get that.

text: Yeah I agree, if I were doing this in a team then cloud would be the best choice but when you are one man band there is a lot to be had by keeping things simple and local. I struggled to move fast when tied to a backtesting framework in the cloud, moving local has opened a lot of doors (for now)

elements.text: Yeah I agree, if I were doing this in a team then cloud would be the best choice but when you are one man band there is a lot to be had by keeping things simple and local. root.text: Has there ever been a situation someone has dumped a bunch of money due to exchange outage? Is this just unhedgeable risk we need to be comfortable living with?

elements.text: Has there ever been a situation someone has dumped a bunch of money due to exchange outage? Is this just unhedgeable risk we need to be comfortable living with?

text: It's 100% unhedgeable. Even if you knew your position exactly (which you often cannot during outages) you can't even do cross-venue hedging because there is no guarantee that both legs of the trade will pay out (given bets on either side can get voided independently ).

elements.text: It's 100% unhedgeable. Even if you knew your position exactly (which you often cannot during outages) you can't even do cross-venue hedging because there is no guarantee that both legs of the trade will pay out (given bets on either side can get voided independently ).
